column1: Jamaica–United States relations are bilateral relations between Jamaica and the United States.
The United States maintains close and productive relations with the Government of Jamaica. Former Prime Minister Patterson visited Washington
column3: several times after assuming office in 1992. In April 2001
column4: Prime Minister Patterson and other Caribbean leaders met with President George W. Bush during the Summit of the Americas in Quebec
column6: at which a "Third Border Initiative" was launched to deepen U.S. cooperation with Caribbean nations and enhance economic development and integration of the Caribbean nations.  Portia Simpson Miller attended the "Conference on the Caribbean--A 20/20 Vision" in Washington in June 2007.

column1: The United States is Jamaica's most important trading partner: bilateral trade in goods in 2005 was over $2 billion.  Jamaica is a popular destination for American tourists; more than 1.2 million Americans visited in 2006. In addition

column1: The Government of Jamaica also seeks to attract U.S. investment and supports efforts to create a Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA). More than 80 U.S. firms have operations in Jamaica
column2: and total U.S. investment is estimated at more than $3 billion. An office of the U.S. and Foreign Commercial Service
column4: actively assists American businesses seeking trade opportunities in Jamaica. The country is a beneficiary of the Caribbean Basin Trade Partnership Act (CBTPA). The United States Chamber of Commerce

column1: U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) assistance to Jamaica since its independence in 1962 has contributed to reducing the population growth rate
column2: the attainment of higher standards in a number of critical health indicators
column3: and the diversification and expansion of Jamaica's export base. USAID's primary objective is promoting sustainable economic growth. Other key objectives are improved environmental quality and natural resource protection
column4: strengthening democratic institutions and respect for the rule of law
column5: as well as family planning. In fiscal year 2006
column6: the USAID mission in Jamaica operated a program totaling more than $21 million in development assistance.

column1: The Peace Corps has been in Jamaica continuously since 1962. Since then
column3: 300 volunteers have served in the country. Today
column4: the Peace Corps works in the following projects: Youth-at-Risk
column7: and the needs of marginalized males; water sanitation
column8: which includes rural waste water solutions and municipal waste water treatment; and environmental education
column9: which helps address low levels of awareness and strengthens environmental nongovernmental organizations. The Peace Corps in Jamaica fields about 70 volunteers who work in every parish on the island

column1: Jamaica is a major transit point for cocaine en route to the United States and is also a key source of marijuana and marijuana derivative products for the Americas. During 2006
column2: the Government of Jamaica seized narcotics destined for the United States
column3: arrested key traffickers and criminal gang leaders
column4: and dismantled their organizations. Jamaica remains the Caribbean's largest producer and exporter of marijuana. The efforts of the Jamaica Constabulary Force (JCF) and Jamaica Defense Force (JDF) enabled cannabis seizures to increase by over 200% in 2006. In 2006
